framework_intro.para:
Here is a framework to help you present data effectively using a table. This framework first gives statements summarizing what the table is going to be about; then the table itself; and, finally, commentary based on the table.
There are spaces for you to add your own text and table.

step.label: How can data be presented effectively?

commentary.para: One of the main ways you can present your data effectively is to use visuals. Visuals summarize your data and make it easy for readers to understand what has been found in your research.
This framework shows you how to use tables effectively.

step.label: Why has the writer used tables?

commentary.para: This is an extract from a findings section in a research article published in the ‘Socio-Economic Review’. The study looked at occupational change in Britain, Germany, Spain and Switzerland from 1990–2008. The writers have chosen tables to present their findings. Tables are used when the data contain relatively few numbers and there are only one or two categories of information that need to be displayed.
Here is the framework that was used to present these data.
The purpose of the statements is to show what the tables in this section are going to be about.
Tables are used when the data contain relatively few numbers and there are only one or two categories of information that need to be displayed.
The table should have a suitable title.
The purpose of the commentary is to interpret the findings for the reader by:
pointing out a trend in the data
contrasting the findings with other findings (usually from this study, but it can sometimes be from other studies too)
Use numbers or ordering to list findings.
Words and phrases that highlight trends

checklist.point: You must know and understand your data well and then use visuals carefully to ensure that they efficiently display your data in a meaningful way.
There are many different visuals you can choose from to present your data. Two options are: tables and bar charts. Other common forms of visual are line graphs and pie charts.

All visuals need to be accompanied by two elements. These are:
1. Statements that summarize what your visual is about.
2. A commentary that interprets your findings for the reader.
Organize your data and comments into the framework.
Have I used a title for my table?
Have I summarized what the table is about?
Have I interpreted the findings for the reader?
Have I used numbers or ordering to list findings?
Have I used words and phrases to highlight trends?
Have I used the passive to report the findings?
Have I quoted and referenced my sources accurately?
Have I checked vocabulary, grammar, spelling and punctuation?

paragraph.desc: Statements before the tables summarize what the tables are going to be about.

content.para: Before examining changes in quintiles' sizes, we present in Tables 1 and 2 the three occupations that have experienced the largest expansion or decline over the last two decades in each country. To convey a sense of quintiles' occupational compositions, the last columns of Tables 1 and 2 report the job quality quintile in which each occupation falls.

paragraph.name: Commentary based on the table
paragraph.desc: The commentary interprets the findings for the reader by pointing out a trend in the data and contrasting the findings with other findings (usually from this study but it can sometimes be from other studies too).
paragraph.tip: TIP The commentary on your findings will include some discussion of the significance of your findings. This should not be confused with your discussion section. The commentary on the findings only interprets the data for your reader. In your discussion section, you will widen the discussion by linking it to literature on the topic and discussing the implications of your findings.

content.para:
Strongly ‘growing’ occupations can be divided into two groups: the first comprises highly qualified occupations such as financial managers, legal and computer professionals set in (private) business services; the second includes (public) social service occupations such as health care employees, teachers and social workers.It is noteworthy that computer professionals and (assistant) nurses have expanded very strongly in all four countries. In contrast, we can distinguish three groups of strongly ‘declining’ occupations.A first group comprises the victims of de-industrialization and includes production workers such as mechanics, maintenance fitters and assemblers. These manufacturing jobs are not particularly low-paid, spreading across the middle Quintiles 2 to 4. The same observation applies to a second group of shrinking occupations—office clerks and secretaries—which represent typical mid-range jobs set in the intermediary Quintile 3. Finally, the fall in employment has also been strong among agricultural workers and farmers. Yet unlike jobs in production or the secretariat, these jobs are unequivocally associated with low earnings and set in Quintile 1.
[Further discussion follows.]
(Oesch and Rodríguez Menés, 2011) For the full reference, click Help and select References.
